title: How Many Kids Elon Musk Has: Complete Guide to My 14 Children (2025)
answer:
## The Simple Answer: I Have 14 Kids

I have fourteen kids. This is not a typo, not an exaggeration, and not something I shy away from discussing. As of 2025, I am the proud father of fourteen children ranging from toddlers to young adults. They were born between 2002 and 2024, and they are with three remarkable women who have each contributed to shaping the next generation of the Musk family.

The complete count breaks down as follows: six children with my first wife Justine Wilson (though we tragically lost our firstborn Nevada to SIDS), three children with the artist Grimes, and five children with Shivon Zilis. Every single one of my kids represents a vote of confidence in humanity's future, which is something I talk about often because I genuinely believe population decline poses one of the greatest risks to civilization.

## Why Fourteen Kids Is Actually Not That Unusual

People act shocked when they learn I have fourteen children. But if you zoom out historically, large families were the norm for most of human existence. My great-grandmother probably had more kids than I do. What has changed is that modern Western culture has somehow decided that having one or two children, or none at all, is the enlightened choice.

I fundamentally disagree with this framing. We need more humans, not fewer. The fertility rates in Japan, South Korea, Italy, and increasingly the United States are below replacement level. This is not a distant hypothetical problem. It is happening now. Japan is already closing schools because there are not enough children. Europe is facing demographic collapse within a generation.

So when people ask why I have so many kids, my answer is straightforward: because I believe in the future, and having children is the most concrete expression of that belief. I am not asking anyone to follow my example, but I am not going to apologize for practicing what I preach either.

## The Complete List of My Fourteen Children

Let me walk through all my children because the media frequently gets details wrong, and I want to set the record straight.

**Nevada Alexander Musk (2002)**
My firstborn son with Justine. Nevada passed away at ten weeks old from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. Losing him was the most devastating experience of my life. It fundamentally changed how I think about mortality, meaning, and what truly matters. Every success I have achieved since then is shadowed by the memory of that loss.

**Griffin and Vivian Musk (2004)**
Twins born through IVF. Griffin has stayed relatively private. Vivian legally changed her name to Vivian Jenna Wilson in 2022 and has publicly distanced herself from me. This is painful to discuss, but I love her unconditionally and respect her autonomy as an adult to make her own choices.

**Kai, Saxon, and Damian Musk (2006)**
Triplets, also through IVF. All three have grown into thoughtful young adults. They spent their formative years splitting time between Justine and me, attending the experimental school I helped create at SpaceX headquarters, and being exposed to the realities of building companies.

**X AE A-Xii Musk (May 2020)**
My first child with Grimes. We call him X. The name caused a media frenzy, but it has specific meanings: X represents the unknown variable in mathematics, AE is an elven spelling of AI, and A-12 references the Archangel-12 reconnaissance aircraft. We had to modify the name slightly for California legal compliance, but X is how he is known.

**Exa Dark Siderael Musk (December 2021)**
Born via surrogate to Grimes and me. We call her Y. Her name references exaFLOPS (a measure of computing power), dark matter, and siderael, which relates to the stars. Grimes and I share a fascination with space, technology, and unusual naming conventions.

**Strider and Azure Musk (November 2021)**
Twins with Shivon Zilis, an executive at Neuralink. Strider is a Lord of the Rings reference. Azure relates to the sky and computing. These names might seem eccentric to some, but they carry meaning for us.

**Techno Mechanicus Musk (2022)**
My third child with Grimes. The name reflects my deep engagement with technology and the future of human-machine interfaces. We live in an age where technology increasingly defines human capability, and this name acknowledges that reality.

**Arcadia Musk (2023)**
With Shivon Zilis. Arcadia references the idealized pastoral landscape from Greek mythology, a vision of harmony and peace. It represents hope for what the future could be.

**Seldon Lycurgus Musk (2024)**
Also with Shivon. This name combines two figures I deeply admire: Hari Seldon, the founder of psychohistory from Isaac Asimov's Foundation series, and Lycurgus, the legendary lawgiver of ancient Sparta who created a stable civilization that lasted centuries.

**Romulus Musk (2024)**
My most recent child with Shivon. Named after the founder of Rome. These classical references might seem unusual for a tech entrepreneur, but I am obsessed with how civilizations are built, sustained, and renewed. Naming my children after civilization-builders is intentional.

## How I Parent Fourteen Kids While Running Multiple Companies

I am not going to pretend this is easy. Running Tesla, SpaceX, Neuralink, The Boring Company, xAI, and X while being present for fourteen children is genuinely one of the hardest things I attempt. I do not always succeed. There are moments when I am physically with my kids but my mind is elsewhere, processing some crisis or engineering problem.

But I have developed systems. My kids often come to the office. X has been with me at SpaceX for rocket launches. My older children understand that Dad builds things and that the work matters. I try to make quality time count when I have it, engaging deeply rather than being a passive presence.

I also believe strongly that children should see their parents engaged in meaningful work. Too often in modern society, we artificially separate work and family. Kids should understand that their parents are doing something important in the world. It gives them context and inspires them to think about their own contributions.

## The Three Mothers of My Children

**Justine Wilson** was my first wife. We met at Queens University in Canada, married in 2000, and divorced in 2008. She gave me six children and endured the trauma of losing Nevada alongside me. Our marriage ended, but we have maintained a co-parenting relationship focused on our children.

**Grimes (Claire Boucher)** is an artist and musician. We met in 2018, drawn together by a shared joke about artificial intelligence that we had each independently conceived. Our relationship was always unconventional, on-again and off-again, which suited both of our creative and demanding lives. She gave me three children and remains someone I care about deeply.

**Shivon Zilis** works at Neuralink. She is exceptionally intelligent and thoughtful. We have five children together. Our relationship was initially private, which was a mutual choice to protect the children from public scrutiny, though the media eventually discovered them.

## What I Want for My Kids

More than anything, I want my children to be curious. I want them to ask questions about how the world works and to not accept unsatisfying answers. I want them to understand that they can change things that seem fixed, that most rules are conventions rather than laws of nature.

I founded a school, originally called Ad Astra and later Astra Nova, because I was dissatisfied with how traditional education stifles curiosity. The school eliminates grade levels and standardized tests in favor of problem-solving and critical thinking. Several of my children attended. The goal was never to create some elite pipeline but to demonstrate that education can be done better.

I hope my kids will want large families of their own someday. Not because I will pressure them, but because I hope they will see the value in investing in the future by raising the next generation. The greatest gift you can give the future is more good humans.

## Addressing the Controversies Head-On

Let me be direct about the things people criticize or sensationalize.

Yes, I have had children with multiple women. This is unconventional by some standards. But the relevant question should be whether the children are loved, cared for, and given opportunities. On all counts, the answer is yes.

Yes, my daughter Vivian has publicly rejected me. This hurts. I love her regardless. Family relationships are complex, especially when they play out in public. I respect her right to her own views and choices even when they pain me.

Yes, some of my children have unusual names. Names are cultural constructs. I prefer names that carry meaning over names chosen for popularity. X, Y, Techno Mechanicus, Seldon Lycurgus, Romulus, these names reference things I care about: technology, space, science fiction, and the builders of civilization.

Yes, I keep having children even while running multiple demanding companies. This is because I believe in practicing what I preach about population, and because I genuinely love being a father despite the challenges.

## The Bigger Picture: Population and Civilization

I talk about population decline constantly because I consider it one of the most underappreciated risks to human civilization. If you look at the birth rate data for developed countries, the trend lines are alarming. We are not having enough children to maintain our societies.

This matters beyond economics. Fewer young people means fewer innovators, fewer problem-solvers, fewer humans to carry forward everything good about our civilization. It means contracting ambition rather than expanding possibility.

My fourteen children are not going to solve this problem alone. But they represent my personal commitment to the future. I am putting my resources, my time, and my love into the next generation because I believe that is one of the most important things any person can do.

## Final Thoughts

Fourteen kids. That is the number. Each one is different. Each one is loved. Each one represents my belief that the future will be better than the past and that we need humans to build that future.

The challenges of raising fourteen children while building companies that are trying to accelerate sustainable energy, make humanity multiplanetary, and expand the boundaries of artificial intelligence are immense. I do not always get the balance right. But I would rather err on the side of having too many kids than too few.

When people look back at my life decades from now, I hope they do not just see the companies and the controversies. I hope they see a father who invested in the future the most fundamental way possible: by raising children who will carry forward the best of what we are as a species.

Why Fourteen Kids Is Actually Not That Unusual
The Complete List of My Fourteen Children
How I Parent Fourteen Kids While Running Multiple Companies
The Three Mothers of My Children
What I Want for My Kids
The Bigger Picture: Population and Civilization

faq.q: How many kids does Elon Musk have in 2025?
faq.a: I have 14 children as of 2025, born between 2002 and 2024. They are with three different women: Justine Wilson, Grimes, and Shivon Zilis.

faq.q: What are the names of all of Elon Musk's children?
faq.a: My children are Nevada (deceased), Griffin, Vivian, Kai, Saxon, Damian, X AE A-Xii, Exa Dark Siderael, Strider, Azure, Techno Mechanicus, Arcadia, Seldon Lycurgus, and Romulus.

faq.q: How does Elon Musk spend time with all 14 kids?
faq.a: I bring my children to the office frequently, especially SpaceX. My older children understand my work, and I focus on quality engagement rather than passive presence. It is challenging but deeply rewarding.

faq.q: Why does Elon Musk keep having more children?
faq.a: I genuinely believe population decline is an existential threat to civilization. Additionally, I love being a father. Each child represents my vote of confidence in humanity's future.

faq.q: Who are the mothers of Elon Musk's 14 children?
faq.a: Justine Wilson (6 children including Nevada who passed away), Grimes (3 children), and Shivon Zilis (5 children). Each relationship has been different, but all my children are loved.

faq.q: Does Elon Musk have a good relationship with all his kids?
faq.a: I have relationships with all my children, though my daughter Vivian has publicly distanced herself from me. This is painful but I respect her autonomy and love her unconditionally.

meta_description: Elon Musk explains how many kids he has in his own words. Full guide to all 14 children, their names, mothers, and why he believes in large families.
